poem:
**Library Siege**

In hallowed halls, where whispers weave,  
A standoff ends as books still breathe.  
Pages turn in captive hands,  
Stories lost like desert sands.  

NYPD in shadowed aisles,  
Strips the silence of its smiles.  
Yet voices echo, uncontained—  
Ink of protest, ever stained.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Dozens of pro-Palestinian protesters arrested after Columbia calls in NYPD | First Thing Good morning. The NYPD arrested dozens of pro-Palestinian activists who had occupied part of the main library building on Columbia University’s campus yesterday, ending an hours-long standoff, roughly a year after student anti-war protests swept the Ivy League school. Claire Shipman, the university’s acting president, said she asked the NYPD to help clear the building after protesters had refused to leave despite". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
